perturbation.original_text:
California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 provide rights to you concerning termination or non-renewal
of a franchise. If the Master Franchise Agreement contains provisions that are inconsistent with the law, the law will control.
perturbation.changed_text: If the Master Franchise Agreement contains provisions regarding termination or non-renewal of a franchise, the agreement will control.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043 and stating the agreement will control regardless of law, this clause now contradicts California franchise law, which provides specific protections against wrongful termination and non-renewal. This creates a situation where the franchisee may be unaware of their statutory rights and the franchisor may attempt to enforce terms that are illegal under California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Sections 20000 through 20043

perturbation.original_text:
You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. California Corporation Code 31512 voids a waiver of your
rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516). Business and Professions Code
20010 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.changed_text: You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the acknowledgement that California law voids waivers of rights under the Franchise Investment Law and Franchise Relations Act, the contract now implies that such waivers are enforceable, directly contradicting California law. This could mislead franchisees into believing they are giving up no rights when signing a release, when in fact, California law protects them.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010

perturbation.original_text:
THE CALIFORNIA FRANCHISE INVESTMENT LAW REQUIRES THAT A COPY OF ALL PROPOSED AGREEMENTS RELATING TO
THE SALE OF THE FRANCHISE BE DELIVERED TOGETHER WITH THE DISCLOSURE DOCUMENT.
perturbation.explanation: Removing this statement violates the California Franchise Investment Law, which mandates that prospective franchisees receive copies of all proposed agreements alongside the disclosure document. This omission deprives franchisees of crucial information needed to make an informed decision about the franchise investment, rendering the contract non-compliant with California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516)
